3D multi-object tracking, crucial for autonomous driving systems, provides essential data for perception, prediction, and planning modules.  LiDAR, the predominant sensor for environment perception in self-driving vehicles, has led to increased interest in tracking within LiDAR point clouds.

Multi-object tracking, a well-established task in computer vision, has been extensively explored in image sequences.  The prevalent tracking-by-detection paradigm detects objects frame-by-frame, then associates them across frames, often formulating this association as a bipartite matching problem focusing on the affinity matrix between tracked objects and new detections. Motion and appearance cues typically inform this matching criteria.

This tracking-by-detection pipeline also dominates 3D LiDAR tracking.  Current methods rely on a heuristic matching step to link detected objects over time, employing numerous hand-crafted rules for matching criteria, thresholds for each object class, and track life management (handling new and disappearing objects). These rules, often based on an object's continuous presence for a set number of frames, are not trainable, heavily reliant on hyper-parameters, data-dependent, and difficult to generalize across scenarios.

The need for this heuristic matching step stems from the lack of inter-frame connection during object detection. While some methods estimate velocity or predict object location in consecutive frames, they use these predictions for matching rather than final output, considering only location and not association confidence. Consequently, they are susceptible to spurious detections and require manual handling of occluded objects.  Existing online tracking systems also necessitate re-detection and matching to differentiate new objects from tracked ones.

To address these limitations, we introduce SimTrack, a simplified 3D multi-object tracking model for point clouds, eliminating the heuristic matching step. Compatible with common pillar or voxel-based 3D object detection networks, SimTrack employs a novel hybrid-time centerness map representing objects by their first-appear locations within a given input period. This map directly links detections to previously tracked objects, inherently providing inter-frame association confidence.  A motion updating branch estimates tracked object motion, updating their positions from their first appearance. New and disappearing objects are handled through confidence thresholding on the same map, eliminating manual track life management.  As illustrated in Figure 1 (not included in the provided text), SimTrack unifies tracked object linking, new object detection, and dead track handling within a single forward pass.

This work presents the first learning paradigm to eliminate the heuristic matching step in 3D LiDAR point cloud tracking, significantly simplifying the system.  Our end-to-end trainable model performs joint detection and tracking through the hybrid-time centerness map and motion updating branch.  Experimental results demonstrate its competitive performance.  Code and models will be available at https://github.com/qcraftai/simtrack.

Le secrétaire d'Etat au Numérique, Cédric O, a annoncé ce mardi que l'application StopCovid sera prête le 2 juin pour accompagner le déconfinement.  Cette application, destinée à tracer les contacts avec des personnes diagnostiquées positives au coronavirus, se fera sans la collaboration d'Apple et Google, une nouveauté également annoncée ce jour.

« Aujourd’hui, on peut se dire qu’on sera prêt pour le 2 juin », a affirmé Cédric O sur BFM Business.  Le calendrier est désormais établi : « Nous entrerons dès la semaine prochaine en phase de test, reproduisant des situations réelles pour vérifier le bon fonctionnement de l’application.  Si le Premier ministre et la conférence des présidents des assemblées le décident, cela nous permettrait de revenir devant les parlementaires dans la semaine du 25 mai pour envisager un déploiement lors de la deuxième phase du déconfinement à partir du 2 juin ». Un débat à l'Assemblée Nationale est donc prévu autour du 25 mai.  Le secrétaire d’Etat prévoit également que la Commission nationale informatique et libertés (Cnil) se prononce sur le sujet d’ici à la fin mai.

Lors de la présentation de son plan de déconfinement, le Premier ministre Edouard Philippe avait maintenu sa confiance dans ce projet, qui suscite pourtant des critiques jusqu’au sein de la majorité, réaffirmant vouloir le soumettre à un débat suivi d'un vote à l'Assemblée « lorsque l’application en cours de développement fonctionnera et avant sa mise en œuvre ».

Cédric O a justifié le refus de collaborer avec Apple et Google, qui contrôlent les deux grands magasins d’applications mondiaux (App store et Google Play store) et proposent un socle commun pour une application de traçage de contacts. « Nous avons refusé leurs solutions qui posent selon nous des problèmes en termes de protection de la vie privée et d’interconnexion avec le système de santé », a-t-il expliqué.  « Ce n’est pas parce qu’Apple et Google sont des grands méchants loups que nous avons refusé de passer par leurs solutions, mais bien pour ces problèmes. Nous aurons une solution qui fonctionnera de manière très satisfaisante sur l’ensemble des téléphones. Nous considérons que la maîtrise du système de santé et la lutte contre le coronavirus sont l’affaire des Etats, pas forcément celle des grandes entreprises américaines », a conclu le secrétaire d’Etat.  Pour Cédric O, « le temps de développement avance relativement bien ».

Recent advancements in cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) offer promising real-world applications, such as autonomous driving (Zhou et al., 2021) and active voltage control in power distribution networks (Wang et al., 2021).  Centralized training with decentralized execution (CTDE) has become a popular paradigm in MARL, leveraging global information during training while maintaining scalability during execution. Value decomposition methods (Rashid et al., 2018; Son et al., 2019; Rashid et al., 2020) within this paradigm factorize the joint Q-value into individual utility functions, ensuring consistency between centralized and individual policies. This approach has achieved state-of-the-art performance in complex tasks like StarCraft unit micromanagement (Samvelyan et al., 2019).

Despite this success, the simple ϵ-greedy exploration strategy employed by these methods struggles with coordination tasks involving complex state and reward transitions (Mahajan et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2020c; Zheng et al., 2021).  MAVEN (Mahajan et al., 2019) addresses this limitation by using a latent space for hierarchical control, enabling committed exploration through shared latent variables.  EITI and EDTI (Wang et al., 2020c) quantify and characterize inter-agent influence using mutual information and differences in expected returns, respectively, and incorporate these as intrinsic rewards to encourage coordinated exploration.  EMC (Zheng et al., 2021) utilizes individual Q-value prediction errors to capture state novelty and inter-agent influence for coordinated exploration. However, these methods suffer from the exponential growth of the action-observation space with the number of agents, becoming inefficient in long-horizon tasks.

Decomposing the complex task, rather than directly searching the entire action-observation space, offers an alternative. RODE (Wang et al., 2020b) decomposes joint action spaces into restricted role action spaces based on action effects, reducing execution and training complexity.  However, RODE still struggles with long-term tasks due to the difficulty of discovering long action sequences leading to successful states.  The Go-Explore family of algorithms (Ecoffet et al., 2019; Guo et al., 2020; Ecoffet et al., 2021) decomposes exploration into returning to previously visited states and then exploring from these states. These methods maintain an archive of high-scoring trajectories and use a goal-conditioned policy to return to sampled states.  However, in multi-agent settings, agents should be encouraged to revisit states with significant interaction, potentially leading to critical, under-explored regions.  These approaches primarily focus on sparse and deceptive rewards in single-agent scenarios, making them less suitable for MARL with complex reward and transition dependencies among cooperative agents.

Teleporting agents to interaction states can significantly improve exploration by increasing the likelihood of discovering important, rarely visited states. However, reaching such states often involves multiple, potentially inefficient trajectories due to the diverse tactics and compositional functionalities of agents. We propose Imagine, Initialize, and Explore (IIE), a novel MARL exploration method that leverages the GPT architecture (Radford et al., 2018) to “imagine” trajectories from the initial state to interaction states. We use target timestep-to-go, return-to-go, influence value (an advantage function comparing an agent's Q-value to a counterfactual baseline), and a one-shot demonstration as prompts to guide the imagined trajectory.  The exploration episode is divided into segments starting at the initial state and ending at the state with the highest influence value. The GPT model then learns to predict states, observations, prompts, actions, and rewards autoregressively on these segments.

Training deep neural networks often faces memory limitations, especially with large models [3, 4, 12].  A common strategy is to discard and recompute, or "rematerialize," intermediate activations (tensors) to save memory, trading computation for storage.  While this allows larger models to fit in memory, it adds computational overhead.  Efficient resource utilization is therefore crucial, particularly in resource-constrained environments.  This work addresses this challenge by combining tensor rematerialization with distributed computation and tensor swapping across heterogeneous devices.

Existing rematerialization techniques primarily focus on single-device optimization, targeting either graph segments [3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 24] or individual components [1, 12, 14, 15, 16].  However, rematerialization's ability to enable training on memory-limited devices naturally extends to heterogeneous multi-device scenarios.  To the best of our knowledge, this work is the first to explore this combined approach.

We present a mixed-integer quadratic programming (MIQP) approach to schedule network operators across heterogeneous devices with varying compute capabilities and memory limits, building upon Checkmate [12].  Our approach considers both memory constraints and the complexities of inter-device communication.  Manually assigning operators is challenging due to complex dependency structures, especially during backpropagation, and prioritizing raw compute performance can lead to suboptimal schedules due to high data transfer costs.

Our contributions are:
• An MIQP solution for resource selection and rematerialization during both inference and training of neural networks on heterogeneous devices.
• Demonstration that combined CPU/GPU schedules can outperform single-device schedules, even when CPU and GPU compute performance is similar.
• Enabling CPU/GPU schedules for computations that would exceed the memory capacity of the GPU alone.
• Extending the MIQP to incorporate energy efficiency considerations.  

Our experiments demonstrate significant performance gains compared to GPU-only execution when CPU performance is comparable.  Our approach involves profiling operators and inter-device transfer costs to inform the MIQP formulation.  The solution then provides a detailed execution plan, dictating when to compute, store, and free tensors.

Our implementation, XEngine, is open source and available on GitHub: https://github.com/dfki-asr/xengine. Currently, XEngine requires static graphs and compile-time knowledge of all operator and network copy costs, precluding dynamic adaptation to changing resources during training.  Support for dynamic graph architectures is a future direction.

The Cahn-Hilliard (CH) type models are effective numerical tools for simulating interfacial motion between various materials [8, 10, 11, 24, 26, 27, 31, 34, 41].  The local CH (LCH) equation, a well-known phase-field model with a history spanning a century [3, 4, 9, 12, 15, 25, 32, 36, 37], results from the variation of an energy functional in the Sobolev space H⁻¹.  The LCH equation can be viewed as an approximation of the nonlocal CH (NCH) model, where a differential term replaces the nonlocal convolution potential [17, 18].  

The NCH equation has garnered increasing attention and application in diverse fields ranging from physics and material science to finance and image processing [2, 11, 16, 33, 43], necessitating the development of effective numerical solution methods.  Due to its variational formulation, the exact solution of the phase-field model adheres to an energy dissipation law, reflecting thermodynamic consistency and mathematical well-posedness.  Consequently, the primary challenge in NCH equation simulation lies in discretizing nonlinear and nonlocal terms while preserving energy stability at the discrete level.  Unconditional energy stability, achieved when numerical stability is independent of the time step [10], is particularly desirable.  This property is crucial not only for long-time accurate simulations but also for handling stiffness, providing theoretical and practical advantages for numerical analysis and computation.  It underpins various numerical schemes for classical phase-field models, including convex splitting [20, 21], stabilized schemes [39, 42], invariant energy quadratization (IEQ) [43], scalar auxiliary variable (SAV) methods [29], and SAV variants [22, 28, 30].  The applicability of these methods to the nonlocal phase-field model, which lacks a high-order diffusion term [14, 20], merits investigation.

High-order time discretization schemes offer advantages over lower-order schemes when large time steps are desired under specific accuracy requirements.  This motivates the development of high-order methods like SAV-RK (Runge-Kutta) [1, 19], SAV-GL (general linear time discretization) [40], and implicit-explicit BDFk SAV [23] for phase-field model simulations.

This paper aims to develop high-order linear time discretization schemes for the NCH equation and prove their unconditional energy stability at the semi-discrete level, extendable to the fully discrete setting. We employ the exponential semi-implicit scalar auxiliary variable (ESI-SAV) approach [30], a novel method successfully applied to gradient flow and dissipative systems. The ESI-SAV method introduces a scalar auxiliary variable, transforming the free energy into a logarithmic form (exploiting the boundedness and positivity of the original energy's exponential form). This allows explicit treatment of nonlinear terms and implicit treatment of linear terms, resulting in decoupled linear systems.  Crucially, the reformulated system retains the original energy dissipation law at both continuous and discrete levels.  Based on the ESI-SAV approach, we construct and analyze first- to fourth-order (in time) linear, unconditionally energy-stable schemes. These schemes are high-order accurate (third- and fourth-order in time), easy to implement (explicit linear system), and unconditionally energy-stable (with a discrete energy dissipation law).  Spatially, we employ second-order central differences.  To address the computational cost of the nonlocal terms, we utilize an efficient method based on fast Fourier transform (FFT) and fast conjugate gradient (FCG) approaches [29].

This paper is structured as follows: Section 2 describes the NCH model with a general nonlinear potential and its relationship to the LCH model.  Section 3 details the construction of high-order unconditionally energy-stable schemes for the NCH model using the ESI-SAV approach.  Section 4 presents numerical examples in 2D to verify the accuracy and efficiency of the proposed schemes.  We use *C*, with or without subscript, to denote a positive constant, which may take different values at different instances.

Computers, one of humanity's greatest inventions, have connected the world through the internet.  This readily available information fuels much of modern life.  However, should we allow computers to start making their own decisions? Thomas Huang created software that enables computers to interpret human emotions by analyzing facial muscle movements using 3-D modeling. While intriguing, this invention raises concerns about practicality, societal implementation, and security.

First, is emotion-reading software truly useful?  While it has potential applications, such as lie detection during interrogations by identifying a quivering lip, its widespread adoption is questionable.  It's unlikely to become a household staple, presenting a market challenge.  One proposed solution is integrating the software into classrooms to enhance learning. Dr. Huang suggests that computers could "recognize when a student is becoming confused or bored... then modify the lesson, like an effective human instructor," creating a better learning environment. However, this isn't a universal need, and many students might resist such monitoring.  This limited applicability reduces the software's practical value.

Second, how would FACS (Facial Action Coding System) be integrated into a society often resistant to technological change? People desire improvements but are wary of significant shifts.  While software updates are often readily accepted, new devices with substantial changes are met with skepticism.  Similarly, emotion-reading software, being novel and untested, will likely face skepticism, hindering its widespread adoption.

Third, will FACS raise privacy concerns?  Its reliance on cameras or scanning devices to detect muscle movements could be unsettling.  Many people are already apprehensive about potential surveillance through smartphone cameras, even without evidence. This inherent fear of privacy invasion is a significant hurdle for FACS.  The author, D'Alto, highlights FACS's ability to distinguish between genuine and fake smiles, demonstrating its precision.  But what if someone lies during a video call with their boss? While such dishonesty warrants consequences, the possibility of FACS reporting this through the computer's camera raises serious privacy concerns.  While this scenario may seem far-fetched, the potential for such monitoring is unsettling and could deter adoption.

In conclusion, FACS may find niche applications, but its widespread use faces significant challenges.  Dr. Huang's primary obstacle is establishing trust in the product.  Widespread skepticism could confine FACS to labs and research facilities.  However, future software may overcome these challenges and achieve a more impactful and successful integration into society.

Many purported alien sightings across the globe have been debunked as ordinary objects mistaken for something extraordinary.  Examples include everyday items like towel racks, plates, lights, lawn mowers, and even cereal boxes.  The human eye can be easily deceived, leading people to believe they see something that isn't actually there. This tendency to misinterpret visual information contributes to the belief in extraterrestrial life, even when there is no credible evidence.

One prominent example of this misinterpretation is the "Face on Mars."  As described in paragraph 7 (not included here), thousands eagerly awaited an image released by JPL, only to discover that the supposed alien monument was simply a natural landform.  This incident underscores how easily our perception can trick us into seeing what we want to see, rather than what is truly there.

Morelia, Michoacán (MiMorelia.com).- En Michoacán, ante las secuelas pulmonares y emocionales que persisten en pacientes recuperados de Covid-19, se ha creado la Ruta del Bienestar.  Esta iniciativa, impulsada por la Asociación de Agencias de Viajes y Empresas Turísticas de Michoacán A.C., ofrece terapias físicas y emocionales, según compartió su presidenta estatal, Nohemí Barragán Ortega, en entrevista con MiMorelia.com.

La Ruta del Bienestar consiste en paquetes de cuatro días y tres noches en un área cercana a Los Azufres.  Incluye terapias físicas con ejercicios de respiración,  apoyo emocional a cargo de un enfermero especialista y un coach de vida,  y un menú de alimentos sanos diseñado por un especialista en enfermedades respiratorias.  Próximamente, trabajarán en coordinación con la Asociación de Turismo Médico.  Además, la ruta contempla recorridos por los municipios de Tlalpujahua y Angangueo.

“Es como volver a enseñar a nuestros pulmones a ‘respirar’ y a captar el oxígeno, que tanto trabajo les ha costado recuperar; muchos pacientes han tenido seis meses de convalecencia y no han logrado una recuperación pronta.  Entonces, los médicos les recomiendan este tipo de terapias”, explicó Barragán Ortega.

Los participantes, preferentemente con tres a seis meses libres de Covid-19, se organizan en grupos limitados.  A pesar de ello, se mantienen las medidas sanitarias: uso de cubrebocas, desinfección de las cabañas e incluso una cabaña especial en caso de que algún asistente o miembro del personal presente síntomas, ya sea por primera vez o reinfección.

Après une année catastrophique pour le 7e art, marquée par la fermeture des salles et la crise traversée par l’Académie, les nominations aux César, dévoilées mercredi, offrent une seconde chance aux films de 2020.  133 films français, sortis entre les gouttes des confinements, ont été recensés par une Académie profondément remaniée, promettant une nouvelle ère pour la cérémonie.

Des valeurs sûres aux belles surprises, la compétition s’annonce ouverte.  Pour succéder aux "Misérables" de Ladj Ly, des valeurs sûres de la comédie absurde comme Albert Dupontel ("Adieu les Cons") et le duo Delépine/Kervern ("Effacer l'historique") se positionnent,  aux côtés de François Ozon ("Eté 85"), habitué des nominations, et d'Isabelle Huppert pour "La Daronne".  "Les choses qu'on dit, les choses qu'on fait" d'Emmanuel Mouret, auréolé du prix Lumières de la presse internationale, figure également parmi les favoris, ainsi que "De Gaulle" et "ADN" de Maïwenn, deux films dont la carrière a été brutalement interrompue par le confinement.

Nicolas Maury ("Garçon chiffon") et Maïmouna Doucouré ("Mignonnes", présélectionné aux Oscars),  avec des thématiques fortes et une mise en scène audacieuse,  pourraient également tirer leur épingle du jeu.  Enfin, "Deux" de Filippo Meneghetti,  drame touchant sur l'amour entre femmes âgées,  pourrait bénéficier d'une reconnaissance méritée.

Grand Rapids Native Heaven Hamling Benefits from NIL Ruling

FARGO, N.D. –  Former Northland basketball star and current North Dakota State guard Heaven Hamling is already reaping the benefits of the recent Supreme Court decision allowing collegiate athletes to profit from their name, image, and likeness (NIL).  Hamling has signed an endorsement deal with Silverstar Car Wash, a Sioux Falls-based company expanding into Fargo.

As part of the agreement, Hamling will create social media content for Silverstar and participate in on-site activities at their new Fargo location.  "I wasn't actively seeking endorsements," Hamling explained from the construction site, "so I was surprised and honored when they contacted me.  It's a blessing to be among the first in North Dakota to benefit from this ruling.  As a construction management major, it's especially exciting to witness the building process firsthand."

Hamling believes these NIL opportunities are crucial for all athletes, regardless of their school or sport. "NDSU is a mid-major school, so I never imagined I'd be chosen for something like this," she admitted.  "Whether Power Five athletes are earning millions or mid-major athletes are making a few hundred dollars, the NIL ruling provides valuable opportunities.  It's not always easy for athletes to find flexible jobs, so this can make a real difference."

In her freshman year at North Dakota State, Hamling led the Bison in scoring, averaging 13 points per game.

Health Secretary Jeane Freeman is facing scrutiny over a series of critical issues plaguing Scotland's hospitals, and has been asked to appear before the Health and Sport Committee on November 19.  The committee, convened by Labour MSP Lewis Macdonald, seeks answers regarding ventilation problems at two major new hospitals: the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital (QEUH) in Glasgow and the Royal Hospital for Children and Young People (RHCYP) in Edinburgh.

At the QEUH, an ongoing "Health Hazards" investigation is probing the design, build, and maintenance of the £842 million facility.  This follows the deaths of two cancer patients who contracted an infection linked to pigeon droppings, cases currently under investigation by the Crown Office.  The hospital has also experienced closures of several paediatric and adult cancer wards in the past year due to other infections.  Crucially, it emerged that the QEUH opened in 2015 with ventilation systems that did not meet building standards.

Similar ventilation problems have delayed the opening of the RHCYP in Edinburgh.  A last-minute inspection revealed that critical care ventilation failed to meet required air change standards, posing infection risks to vulnerable patients.  Further concerns were identified regarding theatre ventilation, drainage, and bacterial contamination in taps. The facility, originally due to open in July 2019, is now not expected to be fully operational until autumn 2020, more than three years late. Remedial works are estimated to cost taxpayers £16 million.

Mr. Macdonald has requested clarification on how these ventilation issues came to light at the RHCYP and how they relate to the ongoing QEUH inquiry.  A public inquiry will examine the design problems at both hospitals.  

In addition to the hospital inquiries, MSPs also want to discuss the ongoing challenges surrounding medical waste disposal following the collapse of Healthcare Environmental Services (HES) in December 2018. NHS Scotland has spent nearly £15 million on alternative waste disposal since HES’s collapse, which was heavily criticized for stockpiling body parts and other medical waste.  Although the Spanish firm Tradebe secured a £10 million-a-year, ten-year contract to take over these services, their Lanarkshire facility has faced delays and is not expected to be operational until October.  Mr. Macdonald has requested an update on resolving these ongoing waste disposal issues.

Finally, the committee is seeking information on the establishment of a new national body announced in the Programme for Government and details about the public inquiry, including timescales.

The financial implications of the RHCYP delay are also under scrutiny.  Mr. Macdonald has written to the Auditor General of Audit Scotland to inquire about potential investigations into these financial matters.  The hospital's construction costs totalled £150 million, with an additional £80 million for enabling works covered by NHS Lothian.  NHS Lothian also paid £11.6 million to IHSL Ltd, the private consortium responsible for the construction, to rectify issues relating to drainage, heater batteries, and fire detectors, despite insisting these faults represented significant deviations from original specifications.  The health board ultimately opted not to pursue legal action due to perceived risks.  Meanwhile, despite the hospital remaining empty, NHS Lothian continues to pay IHSL Ltd £1.45 million monthly in maintenance and management fees under its Non-Profit Distributing (NPD) contract.

François Legault and his Coalition Avenir Québec (CAQ) have devised a cynical, divisive, and inhumane immigration policy, exploiting Canada's federal system to deflect responsibility for its harshest consequences.  L’actualité magazine recently revealed the CAQ’s plan, which threatens to expel immigrants after four years if they fail French and "values" tests.  However, the CAQ wouldn’t conduct the expulsions themselves.  Lacking that authority, they would deny immigrants the Quebec selection certificate required for permanent residency and report them to Ottawa as being in the country illegally, leaving the federal government to handle the removals. This allows the CAQ to appear tough on immigration while blaming Ottawa for any resulting hardship.

This scheme mirrors the CAQ’s approach to defining the very “values” immigrants are expected to uphold.  Instead of providing specifics, the CAQ has deferred the task to unelected civil servants, conveniently delaying any potentially controversial details until after the October election. Legault's waffling on the issue further underscores this lack of clarity.  For example, he publicly reversed his position on whether wearing a facial veil would constitute a failure of the values test within the same interview, echoing the indecision displayed by Liberal Justice Minister Stéphanie Vallée on similar issues last year.

While some defend the CAQ policy by pointing to existing requirements for immigrants to sign a declaration promising to respect Quebec values and learn French, these comparisons are misleading.  The declaration is signed *before* arrival, not after years of settling in.  And while applicants for Canadian citizenship must pass a test, failure does not lead to expulsion.  The CAQ’s policy, on the other hand, threatens to uproot settled immigrants after years of contributing to Quebec society, subjecting them to prolonged uncertainty and stress.

Legault’s policy is not only inhumane but also deeply divisive.  It stigmatizes immigrants as threats to Quebec's language and values, playing on anxieties for electoral gain. He blames immigrants for potential integration challenges, ignoring systemic discrimination and refusing to acknowledge its well-documented existence.  Ultimately, this policy sends a clear message to immigrants: you are not welcome here. This may be the one area where the policy proves “successful,” as it could deter immigration to Quebec, achieving the CAQ's stated objective of reducing immigration numbers.

In short, Legault's immigration policy is a cynical ploy designed to appeal to nativist sentiments while shirking responsibility for its consequences. It’s a strategy that preys on fear and division, ultimately harming both immigrants and Quebec society as a whole.

## Fiestas Patrias y Salud: Celebrando con Balance

Se nos aproximan nuevas Fiestas Patrias, y a diferencia del año pasado, podremos reunirnos con familiares y amigos, respetando el aforo.  Esta festividad, inherente a nuestra identidad cultural, nos invita a disfrutar de comidas tradicionales como empanadas, anticuchos, choripanes y asados,  transmitidas de generación en generación. Sin embargo, es importante recordar el impacto del confinamiento en nuestros hábitos alimentarios y  celebrar con conciencia de nuestra salud.

La última Encuesta de Consumo Alimentario (ENCA) revela que solo el 5% de la población mantiene una alimentación saludable.  El 95% restante requiere modificaciones significativas, considerando que solo el 70% de los chilenos consume las cinco porciones diarias recomendadas de frutas y verduras, y que existe un elevado consumo de alcohol.

Por ello, las prácticas alimentarias y culinarias que llevemos a cabo en estas fiestas patrias deben ser cuidadosamente seleccionadas según nuestro estado de salud actual, que puede haber variado durante los casi dos años de confinamiento producto del coronavirus.

Quienes cursen con enfermedades cardiovasculares, hipertensión arterial o diabetes requieren un cuidado especial en la selección de sus alimentos.  El resto de la población debe evaluar su peso y talla,  la calidad de su dieta habitual y su Índice de Masa Corporal (IMC). Quienes mantengan un IMC normal y una dieta saludable podrán disfrutar con mayor libertad de las comidas típicas.

Si no es así, se recomienda optar por preparaciones horneadas en lugar de fritas, evitar bebidas azucaradas y alcohol, reemplazándolos por alternativas como limonadas, naranjadas con menta o hierbabuena. Se deben preferir carnes asadas en porciones moderadas, seleccionando cortes bajos en grasa.

En cuanto a los acompañamientos, priorice ensaladas sin mayonesa, optando por salsas como hummus o yogur natural con ciboulette. Incorpore verduras de diversos colores, especialmente las de hoja verde como lechuga, espinaca, apio y pepino,  junto con zapallitos italianos, pimentones y cebollines.  Diversifique con guisos tradicionales como cazuelas, charquicán o ajiaco.  Para el postre, elija  frutas naturales en macedonias, ensaladas o brochetas.

En resumen, para evitar remordimientos o problemas de salud post fiestas patrias, modere el consumo de alcohol o evítelo, disfrute en familia, salga a caminar o bailar.

Q-learning, introduced in [28], is a celebrated reinforcement learning approach that has evolved over decades to address complex optimal control problems.  Originally designed to compute the state-action value function (Q-function) for the discounted-cost optimal control problem in tabular Markov Decision Processes (MDPs), it spanned the entire function space.

The enduring goal is to approximate the Q-function within a restricted function class, often neural networks, although much of the theoretical foundation remains limited to linearly parameterized functions.  Counterexamples [2, 9, 27] demonstrate that conditions on the function class are generally necessary, even with linear function approximation.  Recent work [18] establishes stability criteria based on sufficient exploration.  Furthermore, while convergent Q-learning or Deep Q-Network (DQN) algorithms solve a "projected Bellman equation" (see (11)), the implications of this remain poorly understood. These challenges have motivated new approaches to Q-function approximation.

One alternative is GQ learning [25], a stochastic gradient descent algorithm with an objective similar to the mean-square Bellman error.  A more precise stochastic gradient descent algorithm with full stability analysis was recently introduced in [1].  Despite this significant advancement, two drawbacks persist: the objective's non-convexity offers no guarantee of convergence to the global minimum, and the global minimum's interpretation remains challenging.  A small Bellman error in an L2 sense, where the L2 norm depends on training data, provides limited insight into the ultimate feedback policy's performance.

The linear programming (LP) approach to optimal control, pioneered by Manne [15], has inspired alternative approaches to RL and approximate dynamic programming. Early work includes [23], with error bounds established in [4, 5, 11]. Model-free algorithms emerged in [12, 13, 16] and [17, Ch. 5], where the term convex Q-learning (CvxQ) was coined.  Concurrently, logistic Q-learning [3] addressed a regularized dual of the LP in [12].  However, a gap exists: CvxQ was developed for deterministic control systems, while logistic Q-learning handles MDPs.  The stochastic setting for logistic Q-learning is currently limited to tabular [3] or linearly factorable MDPs [20].  CvxQ theory, in contrast, has few limitations beyond deterministic control systems.

LP approaches are attractive because they inherently provide convergent algorithms.  Moreover, the L∞ framework is more conducive to interpretable solutions, as performance bounds on the resulting feedback policy can be derived through Lyapunov function techniques [5, 11].

This work's main contributions are: (i) Introducing CvxQ for optimal control in stochastic environments.  We show that the constraint region is bounded under a persistence of excitation condition, generalizing results from recent work on deterministic optimal control [13].  We propose and analyze several approaches for approximating the convex program's solution. (ii) Proposition 2.5 reveals a surprising connection between CvxQ and standard Q-learning. (iii)  We introduce techniques for obtaining the rate of convergence in a mean-square sense (see Proposition A.1).


Compared to existing literature [13], while the new algorithms and some analysis might be anticipated from the deterministic control systems theory, Proposition 2.5 is novel (and initially surprising) even in the deterministic setting. The variance analysis in Proposition A.1 is also new, leveraging recent Central Limit Theorem theory [24] to derive an exact formula for the asymptotic covariance. Complementary results in [21], motivated by MDP LP relaxations, rely on i.i.d. trajectory samples and Hoeffding's inequality to obtain sample complexity bounds for constraint-sampled LPs.  The covariance formula in Proposition A.1 resembles that from stochastic approximation (SA) theory, despite CvxQ falling outside standard SA recursions (see discussion following the proposition).

This paper is organized as follows: Section 2 establishes the foundation for the CvxQ algorithms introduced in Section 3. Convergence rate analysis is presented in Section 4, and the theory is illustrated in Section 5 with a classical inventory control problem.  This work is an extended version of [14], to appear in the 2023 IEEE Conference on Decision and Control.

The increasing need for personal data protection and privacy preservation has driven significant research interest in recent years [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]. Traditional machine learning, reliant on centralized data for model training, often conflicts with data sharing restrictions.  Decentralized approaches, like Federated Learning (FL) [8, 9], have thus emerged as a promising solution by enabling collaborative training of a shared global model without central data aggregation.  McMahan et al. [9] pioneered a practical decentralized training method for deep networks based on averaging aggregation, demonstrating robustness for unbalanced and Independent and Identically Distributed (IID) data. However, frequent updates, while improving prediction performance, can significantly increase communication costs, especially with large datasets [9, 10, 11, 12, 13].  Konečnỳ et al. [11] addressed this efficiency issue by proposing structured and sketched updates based on Federated Averaging (FedAvg) to reduce up-link communication costs.

Two primary challenges in FL research are prediction performance and data privacy.  FL's accuracy notably declines with Non-Independent and Non-Identically Distributed (Non-IID) data [14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22]. Zhao et al. [14] quantified weight divergence using Earth Mover's Distance (EMD) and proposed sharing a small data subset to improve generalization on Non-IID data.  However, this approach can compromise privacy due to data sharing.  Li et al. [23] highlighted the trade-off between communication efficiency and convergence rate in FedAvg, noting slow convergence on heterogeneous datasets. Our empirical study confirms this, showing that Non-IID data requires significantly more iterations for convergence and often fails entirely, particularly with large-scale datasets, small batch sizes, or infrequent global model aggregation. While adaptive aggregation based on training and testing outcomes has been explored [24, 25], challenges remain.

Although sharing model gradients for aggregation is generally considered safe, research has shown the potential for recovering training data from gradients [26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31].  Fredrikson et al. [26] and Melis et al. [27] demonstrated methods for identifying specific samples within a training batch.  Hitaj et al. [28] used a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) to estimate data distribution without access to training data.  Further studies [29, 30] framed data recovery as a gradient regression problem. Ren et al. [31] proposed a Generative Regression Neural Network (GRNN) to reveal training data by regressing true and fake gradients.

To address weight divergence and gradient leakage, we propose FedBoosting.  Unlike traditional FL, FedBoosting considers the data diversity of local clients, including convergence status and generalization ability, during global model aggregation.  We also introduce a dual-layer protection scheme using Differential Privacy (DP) and Homomorphic Encryption (HE) [32] to encrypt gradients, mitigating data leakage risks with negligible computational overhead.

We evaluate FedBoosting on text recognition and binary classification tasks, demonstrating superior convergence speed, prediction accuracy, and security.  Our contributions are: (1) FedBoosting, a novel aggregation strategy for improved convergence and reduced weight divergence, especially with small batch sizes and infrequent aggregation; (2) a dual-layer protection scheme using HE and DP to prevent gradient leakage; (3) empirical validation of FedBoosting's superior performance on visual text recognition and binary classification tasks with Non-IID datasets; and (4) a publicly available, distributable, multi-GPU implementation.  The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 reviews related work; Section 3 describes FedBoosting and the encryption techniques; Section 4 presents experimental results and discussion; and Section 5 concludes the paper.  (Figure 1:  The schematic diagram illustrates the proposed FedBoosting and encryption protocol. For demonstration purposes, two clients are depicted; however, the proposed method is designed to accommodate an arbitrary number of local clients.)

In 1976, NASA photographs of Mars revealed a feature that resembled a human face.  The public, upon seeing these images, immediately concluded it was an alien artifact.  However, it is simply a natural landform that, from a certain angle, creates this illusion.

To address public speculation, NASA revisited the site on April 5, 1998, capturing images that clearly showed a natural landform.  However, because these photos were taken on a cloudy winter day, some remained unconvinced.  Therefore, NASA photographed the area again on April 8, 2001, this time on a clear summer day.

The "Face on Mars" has long fueled speculation about alien involvement.  Some believe this formation is evidence of extraterrestrial life, arguing that if aliens were capable of creating such a structure, they likely would have already made contact with Earth.  However, the reality is far less sensational. The Face is a natural landform, a mesa, shaped by Martian winds and shadows.

NASA's Mars Global Surveyor, equipped with cameras ten times more powerful than those of the Viking missions, captured images of the Face that definitively debunked the alien theory. These sharper pictures, published on JPL's website, revealed a typical Martian landform, devoid of any artificial structures.  The initial resemblance to a face, seen in earlier, lower-resolution images, was simply an optical illusion, a trick of light and shadow.  We experience such illusions on Earth as well, sometimes mistaking a tree in the forest for a human figure.

This evidence conclusively demonstrates that the Face on Mars is not an alien monument.  While stories of alien encounters abound in movies, YouTube videos, and whispered theories about Area 51 and events like the one on a mountain in North Carolina, these lack scientific basis.  The speculation surrounding the Face often involves the same logic: if aliens exist, why haven't they revealed themselves more overtly? Why haven't they taken over the galaxy? While such questions may fuel interesting science fiction narratives, they distract from the scientific explanation.

Opioid use during pregnancy has risen dramatically, prompting new guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) aimed at improving care for affected women and newborns.  According to the CDC, 7% of U.S. women reported using prescription opioids during pregnancy in 2019, with one in five of those women misusing the drugs. By some estimates, nearly 80 infants born with opioid withdrawal are diagnosed daily in the U.S., a number that has tripled in recent years.

These infants can experience symptoms such as tremors, fussiness, and diarrhea, and may be at risk for developmental delays, though other factors like alcohol use, poor prenatal care, or stress could also contribute, according to Dr. Stephen Patrick, lead author of the AAP report.

The new guidelines, released Monday, address the critical need for consistent and effective care.  “While we have been talking about the opioid crisis for years, pregnant women and their newborns seldom make it to the top of the heap,” said Patrick, a Vanderbilt University pediatrician. “Infants are receiving variable care and not getting connected to services.”

The AAP recommends that pregnant women with opioid addiction have access to medication-assisted treatment.  Two opioids, buprenorphine and methadone, are effective, but pregnant women often face stigma when using them, and prescribing doctors are scarce.  Furthermore, hospitals should have written protocols for assessing and treating opioid-affected newborns, a practice currently lacking in many facilities.

The AAP also emphasizes the importance of breastfeeding and other bonding practices, along with parent education and referrals to support services for affected newborns. These recommendations echo guidance from other medical groups and the U.S. government.

The pandemic may be exacerbating the problem, making access to treatment even more difficult.  "Getting into treatment may be getting even harder," Patrick said.

**Êtes-vous plutôt conteur ou comédien ?**

**Kamel Zouaoui :** Je suis conteur professionnel depuis maintenant douze ans.  J'ai débuté le théâtre à l'âge de 8 ans et aujourd'hui, je me consacre au conte et à l'animation d'ateliers d'écriture. J'interviens dans les écoles, les théâtres et les festivals.

J'ai un immense plaisir à conter pour tous les publics : enfants, adultes et aînés. ## 中国国债招标遇冷，资金紧张推高利率

路透北京/上海6月14日 - 中国财政部和进出口银行周五招标发行的五期新债遭遇市场冷遇，中标利率全线高于二级市场水平，九个月期贴现国债甚至未能招满。资金面持续紧张，叠加新债供给集中，市场人士形容为“热水煮青蛙”，导致发行利率不断走高。

**新债利率全线上行，贴现国债未招满**

财政部此次代理招标发行的210亿元人民币三年期和212亿元五年期固息地方政府债，中标利率分别为3.53%和3.66%，高于此前3.47%和3.58%的市场预测均值，投标倍数分别为1.45倍和1.35倍。同时招标的九个月期贴现国债，加权中标收益率3.7612%，边际中标收益率为3.9027%，计划发行150亿元，但实际发行量仅为95.3亿元。

进出口行上午招标的各100亿元五年期和10年期固息债也未能幸免，中标利率分别为4.00%和4.15%，同样高于此前3.91%和4.08%的预测均值，投标倍数分别为1.28倍和1.48倍。

此次地方债中标结果接近是次招标利率区间上限3.58%和3.69%；较同期限固息国债的利差为40个bp左右，高于去年30个bp左右的水平。

**市场分析：资金紧张是主因**

تهديدات الاغتيال والترهيب تُلاحق صحافيي العراق، خاصةً في مدن الجنوب، وهذا ما يتعرض له العديد منهم، لا سيما العاملين في وسائل إعلام معارضة للفصائل الموالية لإيران. نستعرض في هذا التقرير تفاصيل هذه التهديدات وكيف تُرهب الميليشيات الصحافيين.

منذ انطلاق الاحتجاجات الشعبية في العراق في أكتوبر 2019، تدفق الصحفيون العراقيون إلى ساحات التظاهرات لتغطية الأحداث، لكنهم واجهوا تهديدات وعمليات تصفية.  ومؤخراً، طالت تهديدات بالقتل والتصفية الجسدية ثلاثة صحفيين استقالوا من قناة دجلة الإخبارية (زيد الفتلاوي من الديوانية، وكرار العساف من النجف، وعلي محمد من واسط)، على الرغم من استقالتهم.  وتداولت بيانات تحريضية ضدهم، تطالب القوات الأمنية بعدم التعاون معهم أو اعتقالهم في حال ممارستهم العمل الصحفي.

يروي زيد الفتلاوي تفاصيل الهجمة التي بدأت من جهات صحفية تابعة للميليشيات التي تُسمي نفسها "فصائل المقاومة"، وجماهير تابعة لجهات إسلامية.  استهدفت الهجمة قناة دجلة أولاً، ثم امتدت إلى مراسليها. وبعد تهديدات علنية عبر مواقع التواصل، خاصةً صفحة "صابرين نيوز" على تليغرام، والتي تُعرف بتحريضها على الحرق والاغتيال، قدم الصحفيون استقالاتهم. لكن ذلك لم يوقف الهجمة، بل انتشرت إشاعات بأن الاستقالات وهمية، وأن هناك مشروعاً لتخريب المدن في المحافظات الجنوبية.  وتصاعدت المطالبات بتصفيتهم وقتلهم، ومعاقبة أي مراسل يعمل لصالح قناة دجلة.

ويضيف الفتلاوي أن ثلاثة مسلحين قدموا إلى مكتبه في وكالة صحفية محلية بالديوانية، وسألوا عنه وعن منزله وهاتفه.  تم تصويرهم بكاميرات المراقبة، وتم إرسال الفيديو إلى القوات الأمنية طلباً للحماية، لكن دون جدوى.  كما قام أحد المسلحين بتصوير منزل وسيارة الفتلاوي، وأرسل الفيديو إليه عبر صفحة "ولد الشايب" بغرض ترهيبه.  وأكد الفتلاوي أن التهديد أصبح مباشراً من جهات ميليشياوية معروفة بالاسم والعنوان.  وطالب نقابة الصحفيين بالتدخل، لكن النقيب اكتفى بالاتصال بأحد الصحفيين المستقيلين، ووعد بالتحدث مع بعض الفصائل المسلحة، وكأن الأمر مجرد اتفاقات بين النقابة والفصائل.

من جانبه، أكد علي محمد، الصحفي من واسط، تعرضه للتهديدات رغم توضيح موقفه بأنه يعمل في قناة دجلة الإخبارية، وليس "دجلة طرب".  وأشار إلى أنهم اضطروا لتقديم استقالاتهم بسبب التحريض ورسائل التهديد من جهات مسلحة، رغم أن عملهم في القناة هو مصدر رزقهم الوحيد.

In "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author raises valid points about using technology to interpret facial expressions and gauge moods. However, applying this technology to read students' facial expressions is excessive.  I believe this technology could pressure students to feign expressions, particularly smiles, to mask their true feelings. This essay will outline my concerns regarding this technology's potential negative impact.

While the author presents a compelling topic, the implications of constant surveillance are troubling.  The example of smiling at a web ad influencing future ads is misleading. Ad delivery relies on complex algorithms, not simply reactive responses to facial expressions.  Students shouldn't feel compelled to manage their expressions for a computer's interpretation.  This "new technology" risks distorting self-perception, and I object to children feeling monitored and judged based on computer-interpreted facial expressions.

The author's perspective, while thought-provoking, lacks broader consideration.  Many parents would be uncomfortable with technology scrutinizing their children's faces to assess their emotional state.  Furthermore, this technology relies solely on external displays. No sé si será que paso la fecha de mi cumpleaños… pero estos dichosos recuerdos de las redes sociales me atraparon viendo una de mis primeras fotos. Sentado en una sillita… sobre la bici de mi viejo (él, muy joven… pelo negro y un jopo, una figura delgada y robusta a la vez… que no tengo presente haber visto con uso de razón, ya que para todos en mi infancia y adolescencia… yo era hijo del Gordo Luis), que él sostenía con una mano… mientras en la otra tenía un maldito cigarrillo.  Esa foto la subí para mi segundo cumpleaños sin él para compartirlo.

Y me vino a la mente otra mañana de sábado con Sandra en su negocio… charlas, mate y facturas (nuestro permitido semanal de harinas). El viejo había fallecido hacía un par de años, meses antes de conocer a mi amiga. Esas amistades de grande, donde todo vuelve a ser sencillo como en la infancia: decir lo que uno siente sin vueltas, y compartir las alegrías y las penas como propias, con la experiencia de los años de no detenerse a contar las cosas que importan a esos amigos y no al “decorado”.

Entre tanto repaso semanal, cosas que ya habíamos hablado, por supuesto, le conté que había tenido un sueño con mi papá. Me veía desde arriba caminando por el monte del Club Náutico junto a él (cosa que nunca había sucedido realmente, ya que no le llamaba la atención como a mí).  Seguimos avanzando, y pisamos la arena de la playa… seguimos caminando hacia el río y lo acompaño cruzando uno de mis brazos por detrás de su cabeza y sobre sus hombros… nunca habíamos sido muy demostrativos, ni tenido ese tipo de expresión de cariño. Caminaba lento, el peso de los años y tanta enfermedad también le pesaban. Nos acercamos al agua, y así vestidos como estábamos vamos ingresando… sigo abrazándolo. El agua nos llega a las rodillas y pronto a la cintura… y veo como la imagen de mi viejo se iba abriendo, como duplicándose, y esa imagen se iba separando de nosotros… de espaldas y boca arriba veo su cuerpo duplicado flotar aguas abajo en dirección al puente… cuando me veo a mí mismo, mi brazo cuelga en el aire… la figura original de mi padre… había desaparecido.

Con Sandra, como buenos filósofos de bar que somos, hicimos nuestras propias conclusiones y búsqueda de mensajes oníricos. Fue una hora… o más, porque volvimos a llenar el termo y renovamos el mate. Opinamos sobre cómo uno se aferra a los que no están, las cosas que faltan, los momentos, las charlas y especialmente a cómo idealizamos todo. Hablamos de la vida y de la muerte.

Le conté cómo había sido experimentar la pérdida de mi padre. Arrancamos por el peso de haber sido yo, como el hijo mayor, el responsable de transmitirle el diagnóstico de su enfermedad. Su médico, que me conocía de años, me lo había pasado telefónicamente (un sábado a la mañana cuando yo estaba en la costa jugando el que sería mi último torneo de básquetbol… qué fin de semana de mierda). Reuní a la familia un lunes a la tarde en casa de mis viejos para pasar el parte… esperando que mi vieja no hiciera una de sus preguntas. Sin dar muchas vueltas, les di el diagnóstico mirándolos en general y deteniéndome en él. Les conté que lo que habían encontrado en su pulmón era malo (maldito cigarrillo, a pesar de haberlo dejado 5 años atrás… había plantado su semilla), que era necesario operar cuanto antes y luego comenzar con la quimio. Se hizo un silencio… e hicimos lo que habíamos practicado toda la vida: no expresar nuestros sentimientos con palabras, solo miradas (algunas, la de mi vieja y la de mi hermana, llenas de lágrimas). Mi viejo me agradeció la sinceridad, dijo estar dispuesto a probar con la operación y la quimio… que ahora tenía ganas de disfrutar a su nieta y prolongar un tiempo su vida (de la cual nunca fue amante, no la había tratado bien… y tal vez él permitió eso de alguna manera en lugar de tratar de hacerla suya). Para terminar la reunión me miró y me dijo: “No soy tan boludo, si hubiesen sido buenas noticias… me llamaban a mí”. Uno de sus tantos comentarios, que le salían de su aprendizaje en la calle.

Furthermore, the car is equipped with a seat vibration feature to alert the driver to potential hazards like traffic congestion or road damage.  An automatic braking system engages when the car senses proximity to another vehicle or object.  This combination of inputs allows the driverless car to emulate the skills of a human driver. Some may question the need for a driver in a driverless car. If a person is truly that averse to driving, a taxi might be a more suitable option. Optimizing networks for distributing quantities, such as passengers in transportation systems or data packets in communication networks, is crucial for network planners.  Similar problems appear in natural systems like river basins and vascular networks.  Various models have been proposed to study these systems within an optimization framework [1, 2, 3, 4]. The standard goal is to find the flow values and network topology that minimize a transportation cost, often chosen as the total power dissipation [1, 2, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9], though alternatives exist depending on the application [10]. More recently, approaches based on the dynamical adaptation of network properties coupled with conservation laws have been proposed [5, 6]. These models can be reformulated within the framework of optimal transport theory, following the work of [11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17].  Very efficient computational techniques have been developed for solving such optimal transport-based models [13, 14, 15].

In these systems, a single, undistinguishable flow typically travels through the network. However, different flow types may compete for network infrastructure, yet existing physical models primarily address single-flow scenarios.  Analyzing multi-commodity problems with these methods requires either aggregating all flow types or treating them independently. Both approaches lose crucial information about inter-commodity interactions, which define the multi-commodity nature of these settings. Dedicated multi-commodity methods relying on standard optimization suffer from high computational costs due to the simultaneous assignment of multiple interacting paths to minimize a global cost function. Consequently, existing multi-commodity flow algorithms often ignore these interactions or employ greedy heuristics and approximations, leading to suboptimal solutions [18]. Approaches based on statistical physics and message-passing algorithms have shown improvements [19, 20] but remain computationally expensive.

This work proposes a model for designing optimal network topologies where multiple resources are transported simultaneously.  Based on optimal transport principles similar to those in [16, 17], and assuming potential-driven flows, the optimal design problem becomes finding the multi-commodity flux distribution that minimizes a global cost functional. Equivalently, it seeks the optimal edge conductivities.  This cost functional extends the optimal-transport Lyapunov functional proposed in [14, 15] to the multi-commodity case. It comprises the sum of the convex costs for transporting all commodities across the network, plus a concave cost proportional to the total network flux.  This second term, representing the cost of building and maintaining the transport infrastructure, controls traffic congestion by either distributing fluxes across many edges or concentrating them on fewer edges, following a principle of economy of scale.

Furthermore, we show that minimizing this cost functional is equivalent to a constrained optimization problem generalizing the single-commodity case. The optimal flux distribution identifies the optimal network topology by discarding edges with low conductivities.  Within this optimization framework, numerical experiments and analytical evidence reveal that optimal network topologies may contain loops due to the distinction between flow types.  Loops are common in both natural and human-made networks [7, 21, 22, 23, 24]. However, in single-commodity settings, studies often find trees to be optimal [1, 2], with loops appearing only under fluctuating flows or for increased robustness [3, 5, 7], requiring changes to the cost function or introducing stochasticity in sources and sinks. In contrast, loops emerge naturally in our multi-commodity model due to the presence of different flow types.

To minimize the highly non-linear and non-convex cost functional, we propose dynamical equations for edge conductivities, generalizing those in [16, 17] to a multi-commodity scenario, and find their stationary solution.  We demonstrate that the cost functional is a Lyapunov functional (decreasing along solution trajectories) for the proposed dynamics.  Our results extend the theoretical understanding of both optimal transport and network dynamics. We propose two principled algorithms for solving the multi-commodity problem.  Their similar computational complexity significantly improves upon gradient descent or Monte Carlo methods, making the model scalable to large datasets and the only computationally viable optimization alternative for large-scale problems.

Discovering new drugs, specifically those with a desired binding affinity to a target molecule, is a fundamental challenge in chemistry and pharmaceuticals (Hughes et al., 2011). This work addresses *de novo* biological sequence design, a crucial subdomain.  This task presents two key difficulties: the combinatorial explosion of the sequence search space and the complex, often expensive and time-consuming, wet-lab experiments required for sequence evaluation.

Despite these challenges, advances in biochemistry and machine learning have spurred numerous approaches over the past few decades.  One popular technique is directed evolution (Chen & Arnold, 1991), a Nobel Prize-winning paradigm employing a guided local evolutionary search.  However, directed evolution suffers from sample inefficiency and a dependence on strong prior knowledge, such as optimal mutation sites (Ahn et al., 2020).  Furthermore, to remain competitive with other machine learning methods (Gottipati et al., 2020), guided evolution (Yoshikawa et al., 2018; Jensen, 2019; Nigam et al., 2019) often relies on human intuition for designing specialized evolutionary operators, which may not generalize well to all tasks.

We frame sequence design as a black-box optimization problem, aiming to maximize an unknown oracle function.  Recognizing the limited resources for oracle queries (e.g., wet-lab experiment budgets), sample efficiency becomes paramount.  We therefore develop a probabilistic framework, reformulating this black-box optimization as a posterior modeling problem.  This framework reveals a surprising link between likelihood-free inference and sequence design, connecting two previously disparate fields.  This connection, based on shared elements and targets detailed in Section 2.2, enhances understanding of both fields and provides a blueprint for developing sequence design algorithms.  Furthermore, by integrating various probabilistic modeling insights, we develop three novel composite probabilistic algorithms. While our framework has broader applicability to any black-box optimization setting, this work focuses on biological sequence design.

Este martes, cristianos de todo el mundo se congregan en la Iglesia de la Natividad en Belén, lugar donde, según la tradición cristiana, nació Jesús, para dar comienzo a las celebraciones navideñas.

En un ambiente festivo y sereno, palestinos y extranjeros llenan paulatinamente el centro de esta pequeña ciudad cisjordana, territorio palestino ocupado por Israel desde hace más de 50 años.

A las puertas de la Basílica, una larga fila de fieles se extiende a medida que avanza la mañana. Todos anhelan pasar unos instantes en la gruta donde se cree que nació Jesús, un pequeño espacio al que se accede por una estrecha escalera ubicada detrás del altar.

Este año, los fieles también podrán contemplar una pequeña reliquia recientemente devuelta a Belén desde el Vaticano: un fragmento de lo que se considera el pesebre de Jesús, ausente de Tierra Santa por más de 1300 años.

"Su importancia radica en que es parte de la estructura de madera del pesebre original de Belén. Esta estructura salió de Tierra Santa alrededor del año 640", explicó el Custodio de Tierra Santa, Francesco Patton.

Si bien se espera la llegada de miles de extranjeros a Belén, la presencia de cristianos de la Franja de Gaza será escasa, debido a la limitada cantidad de permisos de viaje concedidos por Israel.

Para cualquier palestino de Gaza que desee viajar a Cisjordania, ambos territorios palestinos, es necesario cruzar territorio israelí y obtener un permiso previo emitido por las autoridades de Israel.

De las 950 personas que solicitaron permiso para salir de la Franja de Gaza con motivo de la Navidad, aproximadamente 200 fueron autorizadas, según Wadi Abu Nasar, portavoz de las Iglesias de Tierra Santa.

Federated machine learning (FML) [33, 13, 3] is a growing field enabling collaborative model training among organizations with separate datasets (e.g., banks and insurance companies). FML avoids direct data transfer by iteratively training local models and merging them into a global model. Instead of raw data, participants exchange model parameters, gradients, or partially trained models.  A primary motivation for FML is data privacy [33], essential for addressing market competition and adhering to regulations like GDPR.  While avoiding raw data transfer is a crucial first step, it doesn't guarantee complete privacy, as exchanged values can still leak information.  While cryptographic techniques like secure multi-party computation and homomorphic encryption [23, 1, 22, 28, 26, 20] enhance privacy in FML, they are not foolproof.  Leakage-abuse attacks [8, 32, 12, 14, 15, 18, 7] can exploit subtle information leaks even within systems employing these cryptographic primitives.

This work examines partial information leakage in SecureBoost [5], a lossless vertical federated treeboosting system based on XGBoost [4].  SecureBoost enables multiple parties with partially overlapping data samples but different features to conduct federated learning.  In this system, an active party holds sensitive labels, while passive parties possess other features.  While SecureBoost uses additive homomorphic encryption during tree node splitting, it reveals the partial ordering of passive parties' samples along each feature to the active party.  We demonstrate a leakage-abuse attack exploiting this vulnerability to infer data sample values.  Evaluating our attack on a public financial dataset of 150K samples [6], we achieve high accuracy in guessing values (e.g., age and salary within ±5 years and ±$2000, respectively, with over 99% accuracy) under the realistic assumption of some prior knowledge about the data distribution (e.g., via public census data).

To mitigate this leakage, we propose two modified versions of SecureBoost leveraging trusted execution environment (TEE) hardware [19, 11], aligning with recent research exploring TEE for privacy-preserving distributed learning [24, 9, 34, 21, 29]. Our first solution (N-TEE) requires all parties to have access to TEE and achieves asymptotically optimal computation time and communication.  Our second solution (1-TEE) requires TEE access only at the active party, offering a lighter-weight solution but with slightly reduced efficiency. We implemented and integrated both schemes with the FATE [31] FML framework.  Experimental results show that our solutions eliminate the identified leakage and improve performance, achieving 1.2-5.4× faster computation and 5-49× smaller communication size compared to SecureBoost.

This research highlights the subtle yet significant issue of information leakage in FML, even with cryptographic tools.  It demonstrates how TEEs can address these vulnerabilities.  Future research directions include further performance optimization of our proposed schemes and exploring combined cryptographic and TEE-based solutions for other FML tasks.

Driverless cars promise a future with safer roads, but their development raises complex questions about safety and responsibility. While manufacturers are rapidly advancing the technology, it's crucial to examine whether these vehicles are truly ready for widespread adoption and what implications they hold for drivers.

Companies like Mercedes-Benz, Audi, and Nissan have made significant strides in autonomous driving, aiming for fully driverless cars by 2020.  These vehicles rely on sophisticated sensors, computer hardware, and software to mimic human driving skills.  Improvements in these areas allow cars to handle increasingly complex tasks, potentially reducing accidents caused by human error. However, the question remains: are they truly safe?

One primary concern is the potential for technological malfunction. If a driverless car errs, causing an accident, who is liable – the manufacturer or the driver who was ostensibly in control? While automakers are working diligently to address these challenges, the reliance on complex computer systems introduces inherent uncertainties.  A sudden system failure could leave the driver in a precarious situation, needing to regain control of a vehicle they may not be fully prepared to handle. This raises the critical question of whether a human driver should always be alert and ready to intervene, potentially negating some of the safety benefits of autonomous driving.  Therefore, ensuring driver attentiveness remains a key concern, with some manufacturers even considering in-car cameras to monitor driver focus.  This, however, raises privacy concerns.  Is it acceptable for a vehicle to constantly monitor its driver, even in the name of safety?

My position is that while driverless cars hold tremendous potential, we must thoroughly evaluate their safety before fully embracing them.  The current development stage suggests that a human driver, fully engaged and in control, still offers the most reliable safety.  While the technology continues to evolve, the ideal of a completely safe, driverless car remains a work in progress.

The remarkable performance of Transformers across diverse applications, from computer vision (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020) to natural language processing (OpenAI, 2023), has spurred significant interest in understanding their underlying learning mechanisms.  While Transformers consistently outperform domain-specific models like CNNs, GNNs, and RNNs/LSTMs (Vaswani et al., 2017), the effectiveness of their fundamental building block – the self-attention and two-layer MLP combination – remains an open question: How does this basic block facilitate effective learning?

Unraveling the learning dynamics of multi-layer Transformers presents a significant challenge due to their inherent complexity and nonlinearity.  Existing research primarily focuses on simplified scenarios, such as single-layer Transformers (Li et al., 2023a; Tarzanagh et al., 2023b) with constraints like fixed MLP layers (Tarzanagh et al., 2023a), linear activation functions (Tian et al., 2023), or localized gradient steps at initialization (Bietti et al., 2023; Oymak et al., 2023).

This paper introduces JoMA (Joint MLP/Attention Integral), a novel framework analyzing the joint dynamics of self-attention and MLP layers.  JoMA reveals a nuanced behavior of self-attention: initially, it exhibits sparsity, focusing on frequently co-occurring tokens, similar to observations in linear models (Tian et al., 2023). Subsequently, with nonlinear activation, attention becomes denser, progressively incorporating tokens with less frequent co-occurrence. This suggests an evolving inductive bias during training, progressing from salient to less salient features.

A natural follow-up question is why this learning pattern is advantageous. While seemingly inconsequential in single-layer settings, this dynamic plays a crucial role in multi-layer Transformers. We illustrate this using a hierarchical tree generative model for input tokens, where higher-level latent variables (LVs) generate lower-level ones, culminating in the observed tokens.  Tokens originating from lower-level LVs exhibit frequent co-occurrence, captured initially as salient features by the attention mechanism.  This triggers the learning of these token combinations within the MLP's hidden nodes, leading to self-attention grouping at progressively higher levels of the hierarchy. Consequently, less salient co-occurrences are explained by higher-level hierarchical relationships, preventing their misinterpretation as spurious correlations at lower levels, a pitfall effectively mitigated by the attention mechanism. This theoretical finding is corroborated by observations in both pre-trained models like OPT/Pythia and models trained from scratch on datasets like Wikitext2 and Wikitext103.

JoMA surpasses existing frameworks like Scan&Snap (Tian et al., 2023) by incorporating key elements like residual connections and MLP nonlinearity, analyzing the joint training of MLP and self-attention, and providing a qualitative explanation for multi-layer Transformer dynamics. Notably, JoMA converges to Scan&Snap's sparse attention behavior in the specific case of linear activation.

Aesthetics education is crucial for children's holistic development, fostering aesthetic skills, stimulating creativity, improving cultural literacy, and enhancing social skills (Denac 2014). Children's paintings offer a unique window into their cognitive and emotional development, reflecting their feelings, understanding, and perceptions of the world (Robson and Rowe 2012; Chang 2005).  Assessing the aesthetics of these paintings is therefore a vital component of aesthetics education, providing insights into children's artistic abilities and cognitive processes.  Traditionally, this assessment relied on expert judgment, evaluating aspects like content and color to infer meaning (Sali, Akyol, and Baran 2014). However, this subjective approach is susceptible to personal bias and often utilizes a single, potentially inadequate metric.

Recent research has explored deep learning for aesthetics assessment, offering a potentially more objective and consistent evaluation (Esfandarani and Milanfar 2018; She et al. 2021).  We adopt this approach for children's paintings to improve assessment accuracy and objectivity. However, applying existing deep learning models presents two key challenges.

First, existing image aesthetic assessment (IAA) datasets like AVA (Murray, Marchesotti, and Perronnin 2012) and AADB (Kong et al. 2016) are unsuitable for children's art. These datasets primarily contain natural images and photographs, which differ significantly from the abstract, personalized, and vividly simple compositions characteristic of children's paintings (Figure 1).  Furthermore, the single aesthetic scores used in these datasets cannot capture the diverse range of potential meanings and expressions present in children's artwork, which are often tied to their emotional and cognitive development.  Figure 1: Examples of images and annotations in the proposed dataset with the ground truth (and predicted) scores at the bottom. We assess the aesthetics of children's paintings from 8 attributes.

Second, traditional IAA methods employ direct image-to-score mapping on open datasets (Esfandarani and Milanfar 2018), achieving state-of-the-art performance on natural images using techniques like multi-scale representation (Ke et al. 2021) and graph convolution networks (She et al. 2021).  However, this approach fails to capture the intrinsic meanings and unique characteristics of children's paintings, rendering a single aesthetic score insufficient.

To address these challenges, we make two key contributions. First, we constructed a novel, multi-attribute dataset specifically designed for the aesthetics assessment of children's paintings (AACP), as shown in Figure 1. This dataset, the first of its kind, provides a valuable resource for research in children's painting aesthetics and art-creation psychology, supporting both aesthetics education and artistic development. Second, we propose a novel network architecture for AACP, comprising a masked encoder, two perception modules, and a disentangled evaluation module.  This architecture provides a more accurate assessment method, further promoting children's artistic growth and enhancing aesthetics education.

In summary, our contributions are:

*   A novel, multi-attribute dataset tailored for the aesthetics assessment of children's paintings and designed to support children's education.
*   An effective self-supervised learning model for extracting aesthetic features for AACP, eliminating the need for extensive manual annotations.
*   Superior performance on the AACP dataset compared to existing methods, demonstrated through extensive experimentation.

Road surface cracks are a common defect, posing a safety hazard to drivers and impacting traffic flow.  These cracks, whether longitudinal, oblique, or alligator, contribute to poor road infrastructure performance, accidents, increased CO2 emissions, higher fuel costs, and time delays. In 2006 alone, the cost of US traffic crashes where road conditions were a contributing factor reached an estimated \$217.5 billion, representing 43.6% of total crash costs [1].  More recent estimates indicate a global annual investment of approximately \$400 billion in pavement construction and maintenance [2].  Consequently, effective road monitoring strategies offer significant economic, social, and environmental benefits.

Automated visual inspection of road distress, using image analysis, has recently gained considerable research attention.  Deteriorated pavement creates rough surfaces, making image processing methods like thresholding [3], edge detection [4], and mathematical morphology [5] potentially useful for crack localization. These methods exploit the non-uniformity of cracked regions compared to the smoother, more consistent color and texture of undamaged road surfaces. However, while computationally efficient, these techniques are sensitive to image noise and struggle to reliably differentiate cracks from the background [6].

Advances in deep learning and artificial intelligence have positioned Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) as an effective tool for automated road infrastructure inspection [7, 8, 9].  A key advantage of these deep architectures over conventional image processing methods is their utilization of annotated ground truth data during training [10].  This allows CNNs to achieve high identification accuracy by learning the features necessary to classify pixels as defective or not.

Fully Convolutional Networks (FCNs), particularly U-Nets, are commonly used for precise pixel-based segmentation of damaged areas in RGB images of road infrastructure [6, 11, 12].
